It would move even you, Judge, to hear how he talk' about that step I want to take; its danga, its temptation. How it is the duty of a Catholic to stan' everything till the las' extreme. I want to see Lalie at mass hereafter on Sundays, or you will hear from me;' and I shook my stick under her nose. Since then the child has never missed a Sunday. utterance: You know how No. 22 can pull at the start; and there was that little imp keeping abreast of her 'most under the thing's wheels. I shouted at him. speaker: Mr. Hudson

utterance: Then Spunky, she shied; and Wash he bounced against the side of that car and back, like a rubber ball, and laid in the ditch till we carried him inside. I've wired down the road for Doctor Campbell to come up on 14 and do what he can for him.

utterance: My father loves me, tante Pélagie, and such will not be his wish when he knows. Oh! it is as though a weight were pressing me backward here. I must live another life; the life I lived before. I want to know things that are happening from day to day over the world, and hear them talked about. I want my music, my books, my companions. If I had known no other life but this one of privation, I suppose it would be different. If I had to live this life, I should make the best of it. Will you be so kine an' stan' jis like you is dah at yo' i'onin', an' lef me take yo' picture?' I 'lowed I gwine make a picture outen him wid dis heah flat-i'on, ef he don' cl'ar hisse'f quick. An' he say he baig my pardon fo' his intrudement. All dat kine o' talk to a ole nigga 'oman! Dat plainly sho' he don' know his place.
speaker: Aunt Dicey

utterance: Good moʼnin', madam. Will you be so kine an' stan' jis like you is dah at yo' i'onin', an' lef me take yo' picture?'
speaker: Archie Sublet

utterance: W'at you want 'im to say, Aunt Dice?
speaker: Martinette

utterance: I wants 'im to come in heah an' say: 'Howdy, Aunt Dicey! will you be so kine and go put on yo' noo calker dress an' yo' bonnit w'at you w'ars to meetin', an' stan' 'side f'om dat i'onin'-boa'd w'ilse I gwine take yo' photygraph.' Dat de way fo' a boy to talk w'at had good raisin'.
speaker: Aunt Dicey

utterance: Howdy, Aunt Dicey! will you be so kine and go put on yo' noo calker dress an' yo' bonnit w'at you w'ars to meetin', an' stan' 'side f'om dat i'onin'-boa'd w'ilse I gwine take yo' photygraph.'
speaker: Aunt Dicey

utterance: I reckon it's Wilkins tells you how the folks they talk, yonda up to Mr. Hallet's.
speaker: Martinette

utterance: How come you didn' bring nuttin' f'om de sto', Martinette?
speaker: Evariste

utterance: No, I did n' go yonda;
speaker: Martinette

utterance: You got to go take back that money; you mus' n' git no picture took.
speaker: Martinette

utterance: But, Martinette,
speaker: Evariste

utterance: I promise' 'im; an' he's goin' give me some mo' money w'en he finish.
speaker: Evariste

utterance: If he give you a ba'el o' money, you mus'n' git no picture took. You know w'at he want to put un'neath that picture, fo' ev'body to read?
speaker: Martinette

utterance: He's goin' to write: This is one 'Cajun o' the Bayou Têche.'
speaker: Martinette

utterance: How you know?
speaker: Evariste

utterance: I yeard so. I know it's true.
speaker: Martinette

utterance: I reckon you jus' as well go care dat two dolla' back, tomo' mo'nin'; me, I'll go yonda ketch a mess o' fish in Carancro lake.
speaker: Evariste

utterance: Isn't that Martinette out there, Wilkins?
speaker: Mr. Hallet

utterance: Dat's who, suh,
speaker: Wilkins

utterance: She ben standin' dah sence mos' sun-up; look like she studyin' to take root to de gall'ry.
speaker: Wilkins

utterance: What in the name of goodness does she want? Ask her what she wants. Tell her to come in to the fire.
speaker: Mr. Hallet

utterance: Bonjou',
speaker: Martinette

utterance: Hold on, Martinette! what's all this pantomime business? Speak out, little one.
speaker: Mr. Hallet

utterance: My popa don't want any picture took,
speaker: Martinette

utterance: My popa ent one low-down 'Cajun. He ent goin' to stan' to have that kine o' writin' put down un'neath his picture!
speaker: Martinette

utterance: Yere you li'le boy,
speaker: Evariste

utterance: You ought not lef dat li'le chile go by hisse'f comme ça in de pirogue.
speaker: Evariste

utterance: W'en I done swim to de sho' wid 'im,
speaker: Evariste

utterance: I hurry yonda to Jake Baptiste's cabin, an' we rub 'im an' warm. 'im up, an' dress 'im up dry like you see. He all right now, M'sieur; but you mus'n lef 'im go no mo' by hisse'f in one pirogue.
speaker: Evariste

utterance: You will let me make your picture now, I hope, Evariste,
speaker: Mr. Sublet

utterance: I want to place it among things I hold most dear, and shall call it A hero of Bayou Têche.'
speaker: Mr. Sublet

utterance: No, no,
speaker: Evariste

utterance: it's nuttin' hero' to take a li'le boy out de water. I jus' as easy do dat like I stoop down an' pick up a li'le chile w'at fall down in de road. I ent goin' to 'low dat, me. I don't git no picture took, va!
speaker: Evariste

utterance: I tell you, Evariste, let Mr. Sublet draw your picture, and you yourself may call it whatever you want. I'm sure he'll let you.
speaker: Mr. Hallet

utterance: Most willingly,
speaker: Mr. Sublet

utterance: It's a bargain?
speaker: Evariste

utterance: A bargain,
speaker: Mr. Sublet

utterance: Popa, you betta come home an' put on yo' otha pant❜loon' an' yo' good coat.
speaker: Martinette

utterance: And now, what shall we call the much talked-of picture?
speaker: Mr. Hallet

utterance: You will put on'neat' de picture,
speaker: Evariste

utterance: Dis is one picture of Mista Evariste Anatole Bonamour, a gent'-man of de Bayou Têche.'
speaker: Evariste

utterance: M'amie, let us go away from this country that is so triste. Let us go to Paris, you and me.
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Yes, Paris would surely be gayer than Bayou St. John,
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: Paris, or anywhere with you - ah, bon Dieu!
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: You will go with me, m'amie? I love you - oh, I love you! Will you not go with me, m'amie?
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Anywhere, anywhere,
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: I have offended you and I would rather die!
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Do not banish me from your presence that is life to me. Let me lie at your feet, if only for a moment, in which to hear you say that you forgive me.
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: You must know what has brought me,
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Through all these months I have never ceased to love you and to long for you. Night and day the sound of your dear voice has been with me; your eyes
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: You cannot have forgotten that you loved me not long ago,
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: that you were ready to follow me anywhere, anywhere; do you remember? I have come now to ask you to fulfill that promise; to ask you to be my wife, my companion, the dear treasure of my life.
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Can you not feel - can you not understand, mon ami,
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: that now such a thing-such a thought, is impossible to me?
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: Impossible?
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Yes, impossible. Can you not see that now my heart, my soul, my thought - my very life, must belong to another? It could not be different.
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: Would you have me believe that you can wed your young existence to the dead?
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: My husband has never been so living to me as he is now,
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: Every object that surrounds me speaks to me of him. I look yonder across the marais, and I see him coming toward me, tired and toil-stained from the hunt. I see him again sitting in this chair or in that one. I hear his familiar voice, his footsteps upon the galleries. We walk once more together beneath the magnolias; and at night in dreams I feel that he is there, there, near me. How could it be different! Ah! I have memories, memories to crowd and fill my life, if I live a hundred years!
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: Then, Madame, there is nothing left for me but to take my leave. I bid you adieu.
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Do not be offended, mon ami,
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: You are going to Paris, I suppose?
speaker: Madame Delisle

utterance: What does it matter where I go?
speaker: Sépincourt

utterance: Oh, I only wanted to wish you bon voyage,
speaker: Madame Delisle
